This is a brief introduction to the reasons.
There are many paths to entering the Way.
To put it simply, it does not go beyond two kinds.
One is entry through principle.
The other is entry through practice.
As for entry through principle,
it means relying on the teachings to awaken to the ultimate truth.
Deeply believe that all sentient beings share the same true nature.
It is just that they are covered by adventitious delusions and false thoughts, and thus cannot manifest it.
If one abandons delusion and returns to the truth, and abides in silent observation,
without self or other, the sages and ordinary beings are equal and one, firmly abiding without moving.
One does not follow the written teachings anymore.
This is precisely in accord with principle, without any discrimination.
Tranquil and inactive, it is called entry through principle.
As for entry through practice,
it refers to the four practices.
All other practices are included within these.
What are the four?
First, the practice of repaying enmity.
Second, the practice of following conditions.
Third, the practice of seeking nothing.
Fourth, the practice of conforming to the Dharma.
What is the practice of repaying enmity?
It means when a practitioner of the Way experiences suffering, they should think to themselves:
I have been wandering in the various realms of existence, forsaking the fundamental and following the superficial for countless eons in the past.
I have given rise to much enmity and resentment, causing harm without limit.
Although I am now without offense, it is my past misfortune and evil karma that have ripened.
This is not something that can be seen or given by gods or humans.
I willingly accept it without any resentment or complaint.
The sutra says:
When encountering suffering, do not be sorrowful.
Why is this?
Because one has insight.
When this mind arises, it accords with principle.
Because it takes enmity as an opportunity to progress on the path, it is called the practice of repaying enmity.
Second, the practice of following conditions.
Sentient beings have no self and are all turned by the power of karma.
Suffering and joy are equally experienced and all arise from conditions.
If one obtains superior rewards, fame and honor, etc.,
This is because of the karmic causes from my past that have now been realized.
When conditions are exhausted, it will disappear again. What joy is there? Gain and loss follow conditions, and the mind has no increase or decrease.
The wind of joy is unmoving, and one secretly accords with the Way.
Therefore, it is called the practice of following conditions.
Third, the practice of having nothing to seek.
People in the world are long deluded, greedy and attached everywhere.
This is called seeking.
The wise one realizes the truth and turns against worldly affairs.
Settling the mind in non-action, the body follows the transformation.
The myriad existences are empty, with nothing to wish for.
Merit and darkness always follow each other.
Dwelling in the three realms for a long time is like a burning house.
Having a body is all suffering, who can be at ease?
Clearly understanding this, one abandons all existence, rests the mind, and has nothing to seek.
The sutra says:
Having something to seek is suffering, having nothing to seek is bliss.
Judging from this, having nothing to seek is truly the practice of the Way.
Therefore, it is called the practice of having nothing to seek.
Fourth, the practice of conforming to the Dharma.
The principle of inherent purity is called the Dharma.
This principle is empty of myriad characteristics, without defilement, without attachment, without this and without that.
The sutra says:
The Dharma is devoid of sentient beings,
because it is free from the defilements of sentient beings.
The Dharma is devoid of self,
because it is free from the defilements of self.
If the wise ones are able to believe and understand this principle,
they should practice in accordance with the Dharma.
The essence of the Dharma is free from stinginess.
One should practice giving and generosity with one's body, life, and wealth without being stingy.
One should understand the three kinds of emptiness, not relying on or attached to them.
One should only remove defilements and transform sentient beings without grasping at characteristics.
This is one's own practice.
One is also able to benefit others.
One is also able to adorn the path to enlightenment.
Giving is like this.
The other five perfections are also the same.
One practices the six perfections in order to eliminate false thoughts, but without any practice.
This is called practicing in accordance with the Dharma.
